Tower is the only GUI tool I use. There are some minor things which will hopefully change, but I really like the UI in general. However I got it with student discount (also wouldn't have paid the full price).
Try http://gitboxapp.com/ , have a free version.

@jonesy Ditto: my employer bought some horrible Zope-y time tracking system (every feature we'd been promised was "Oh, that's not ready yet but you can write an extension") and I thought Python was like Java but slower until I gave it a second look
the experimental GitX seems cooler than gitbox
git
@manuw git
Tower is the best one I've used yet.
@jow git-gui serves the purposes for me too, I just need visuals of the graph
@coderanger is that useable now? Last time I tried it was pretty unstable ... but that was about a year or so ago.
I'm currently using the guis provided directly by git. But I'm going to try out SmartGit 2 since that seems to be the only other GUI that isn't Mac only but runs on Windows...
@jow Can't say I've ever had a problem, but I do all my heavy lifting (everything that isn't commit or push) from a command line or sometimes gitk
@jow For Windows there is always TortoiseGit, which I confess I do use sometimes for small changes when I'm too lazy to open up a terminal.

Every time I look at GUIs for any version control system, I'm usually pretty quick to look around and close out...  I've got plenty of RAM and CPU power, but the resource usage just drives me nuts with most GUIs.  Especially when the terminal is always open while I'm on a computer and typing a command here or there is so much faster than doing stuff in a GUI (for me).
Anyone know of any GUIs that don't consume a lot of resources that I can tinker with?
@codemoran for osx, GitX
one issue is that they are likely trying to do the processing up front to make a responsive UI. I think you're going to trade light resource usage with slower operation overall.
+1 for Tower
I'd like to know what use is there for a git gui?
the command line tool is very powerful
and all the guis make it harder to use git imho
@pimeys imho staging (especially with small hunks) is much easier with a GUI. I also use it to get a quick overview of the current branches in a "tree view".
@mrtazz we use git flow for branches and if I need a graph I use giggle
Yeah, GitX makes staging incredible.
Tower is by far the best for less-technical users. I gave it to the HTML/CSS developer I work with (who's never really used version control before) and she picked it up straight away.
some linux-compatible that is not the builtin git-gui?
@j4mie i also recommend gitbox. Depends on the degree of  non-technical-ness :)
Why don't use CLI?
because variety is good? :P I work on the cli no problem, but I sometimes like to pull up GitX to stage stuff, and get an overall picture of the code
If you are an emacs user, check out Magit. Great tool.
Gity’s alright but the last time we tried it had some issues. I recommend brotherbard’s version of GitX: https://github.com/brotherbard/gitx
To skim through the latest commits or other branches I like gitg on Gnome and gitx on OS X. I'm faster using the CLI for the remaining jobs, though.
On OSX I've found Gity to be a pretty good replacement for gitk: http://gityapp.com/
And if you use vim, fugitive is an excellent plugin.
fugitive for vim is great though :)
If I get in the zone I tend to do too many different changes without committing. Gitx (any GUI really) is great for sorting through that stuff without wading through `git add -i`
I use qgit once a while to tracking the changes of files
Tortoise git is now on Windows and Linux and it is great.
Also Tortoise HG avail
